questiontext.text:
Standard antiderivatives

We have seen previously this week, that we can build up a repository of standard derivatives of functions, which enables us to differwentiate a wider range of functions without having to revert to first principles arguments, We can do something similar for integrations. The most important standard indefinite integrals are given in the following table.


Table of indefinite integrals
\(\displaystyle\int x^n\,dx=\frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}+C\quad (n\neq-1) \)\(\displaystyle\int \frac1x\,dx=\ln(x)+C \)
\(\displaystyle\int e^x\,dx=e^x+C \)
\(\displaystyle\int \sin(x)\,dx=-\cos(x)+C \)
\(\displaystyle\int \cos(x)\,dx=\sin(x)+C \) \(\displaystyle\int \sec^2(x)\,dx=\tan(x)+C \)
